name: Composite Quantity with Units
description: The CQ data type is used to specify a quantity along with its units of measure. It provides a structured way to represent measurements, dosages, durations, and other quantified values commonly used in healthcare. This data type ensures that numeric values are always accompanied by their appropriate units, preventing ambiguity in clinical and administrative data exchange.

CQ.1.name: Quantity
CQ.1.description: The numeric value representing the amount or quantity. This component contains the actual measurement value.

CQ.2.name: Units
CQ.2.description: The units of measure for the quantity. Specifies what the numeric value represents (e.g., mg, mL, hours, days).

constraints.meaningfulUse: At least one component should be populated for meaningful quantity representation
constraints.unitConsistency: Units should be appropriate for the type of quantity being measured
constraints.precisionHandling: Numeric precision should match clinical or administrative requirements

usage: Laboratory test results and reference ranges
commonFields: OBX.5 - Observation Value for numeric results with units
Various quantity fields requiring units throughout HL7 messages

generationHints.typical: Use realistic healthcare quantities appropriate for medications, lab values, and measurements
generationHints.medications: Common dosage amounts (5mg, 250mg, 500mg, 1g) with appropriate units (mg, g, mL, tablets)
generationHints.vitals: Realistic vital sign values with standard units (mmHg, bpm, °C, °F)
generationHints.labValues: Laboratory reference ranges with proper units (mg/dL, mmol/L, IU/L)
generationHints.timing: Healthcare-relevant time intervals (q6h, q8h, q12h, PRN) with time units

validationRules.numericValidation: CQ.1 must be a valid numeric value when populated
validationRules.unitConsistency: CQ.2 units should be appropriate for the measurement type
validationRules.clinicalReasonableness: Quantities should be within clinically reasonable ranges
validationRules.precisionAppropriate: Decimal precision should match the measurement accuracy
validationRules.unitStandardization: Use standard healthcare units when possible

clinicalContext.dosing: Critical for medication dosing accuracy and patient safety
clinicalContext.monitoring: Essential for tracking patient measurements and vital signs
clinicalContext.laboratory: Required for proper interpretation of lab results
clinicalContext.interoperability: Enables consistent quantity representation across systems

relatedDataTypes.NM: Numeric - used in CQ.1 for the quantity value
relatedDataTypes.CE: Coded Element - used in CQ.2 for units specification
relatedDataTypes.MO: Money - for monetary quantities with currency
relatedDataTypes.ST: String - for simple text-based quantities without formal units

implementationNotes.safety: Proper unit specification is critical for patient safety in medication orders
implementationNotes.precision: Consider appropriate decimal precision for different measurement types
implementationNotes.standardization: Use standardized unit codes (UCUM, LOINC) when available
implementationNotes.validation: Implement range checks for clinical reasonableness
implementationNotes.conversion: May require unit conversion capabilities for system integration

unitStandards.UCUM: Unified Code for Units of Measure - preferred standard for healthcare units
unitStandards.LOINC: Logical Observation Identifiers Names and Codes - includes unit specifications
